comments.commentBody: It may well be time to puncture the technocratic, right-wing balloon but just who is going to do that?  The only that can be achieved is through the ballot box and frankly I don't see that coming.  In America the mantra of big, bad, government has convinced too many of the population that government inhibits what everyone wants to be -- rich.  Only when people that government representing themselves exists to benefit all and not just those with the right connections will we see a significant change in the system.

There are plenty of great ideas out there for reducing the deficit, including a good many that won't destroy our country. How is it that 12 hand-picked Senators and Representatives cannot put together some sort of balanced plan? In this time of historically low tax rates, can't they at least agree to raise the capital gains back to 28 or even just 22%? Can't they raise the income cap for contributions to Social Security? Two little things that can go a long way.

When an illegal enemy combatant is captured on the field of war our ONLY legal obligation is to respect his funeral customs after we bury him.

If you DON'T catch him on the field of battle, then there has to be a review board rather than a field summary execution by a junior officer (enlisted men may only make that decision under special circumstances) and the prison must be, if possible, returned to a safe area in the rear for trial or released on the spot.

The LOAC is specific on some things, grey on others, but on the subject of combatants that don't wear uniforms and primarily attack civilians it is VERY clear. Execution is not only permitted, it is virtually mandatory.

"If it is in fact a "War on Terror," then enemy combatants should receive those benefits as defined by the Geneva Convention."

Read behind a bit, and forget about the Geneva conventions that the section on prisoners applies only to LAWFUL combatants. Not terrorists. The section of the Laws of Armed Combat on Unlawful combats is very clear. If you catch them, you shoot them once their unlawful status is determined. Any lessor situation is one they should appreciate. At least while they are alive there is a chance some idiot will either let them go or "trade" them for a US soldier (bad example Israel, my HS graduation present was a combat knife, not something issues to US forces normally, so I could fight to the end and not get captured by the Russians while defending Europe. Captured soldiers are expended soldiers whose only potential wartime value is in their ingenuity when it comes to frustrating their captors. McCain for instance drove the North Vietnamese nuts because of his attitude under captivity. And, I'll note, I'll listen to one of those Arab prisoner tell how the CIA tortured them after they go through a month of what McCain went through at the hands of the North Vietnamese . . .

After all, if torture is so bad why are we normalizing relations with "those animals" (how I heard our military referred to by the progressive left in a sound clip at an occupy XXX sitin). Guess torture is only bad if you can define it the way you want to at the time, and apply that definition for maximum political advantage. If there is no political advantage there is no torture. An odd paraphrase of modern journalistic practices. What bleeds leads.

there seem to be 2 sides to the usa justice coin, and it always lands on the side that shows injustice. on the one side, they incarcerate people who have never been proven guilty of any crime, and, on the side, they dont investigate americans when there is clear evidence of a war crime.
where is the investigation of the 9 afghan kids who were blasted by an apache while they were collecting firewood [3/11]? the usa gov has the video and audio, just like in the reuters kill. the gunners could clearly see that they were just children. nothing has been done or said since the 'apology' for the 'mistake' and the promise to investigate. how would americans like to have to collect the bloody ears, feet, guts of their children?
justice in america is no longer blind. it's now blind, deaf, and dumb.

Gee these folks are enemy combatants, not in the US justice system and are not entitled to the various protections that the constitution affords.  Now you can argue that we should apply them for our own best interests, but not that we must.

Dear NYT,
Does President Obama have any responsibility for anything in your opinion?
The newest de facto amendment to the constitution appears to read: "Might makes right."

The willful obtuseness of Americans willing to buy into a 'security state' never ceases to amaze me. The points of rebuttal are many:
1. This is exactly the same kind of behavior on the part of our government for which we condemned the Soviet Union from Stalin through Brezhnev, for which we criticized Mao and the Cultural Revolution in China, for which we held Apartheid era South Africa a nation outside of the brotherhood of nations.
2. About some things, Orwell was right, albeit 17 years late in becoming a reality. The truism of '1984' was the imposition of a permanent state of war and its concomitant state of fear. Franklin was right when he said that " Those who would sacrifice liberty for security deserve neither liberty nor security." That is the position we are now in, neither free nor secure, despite the longest period of 'war' in the history of our nation.
3. Some posters blindly buy in to the conceit that these men were captured on the battlefield. In many cases this is manifestly false. In some cases, especially of the Chinese Uighurs, the US had paid 'allied' fighters a bounty to produce 'enemy combatants' and they did so with no other motive than greed.
4. This is a matter of war, and it could never impact our own constitutional rights here at home. Think again. Secret Courts and secret findings? A secret opinion authorizing the assassination of an American citizen abroad? It's only a thin slip before it becomes an authorization to assassinate dissenters here in our own country. Paranoid? Maybe so, but no more so than those who so blindly embrace the 'security state.'
5. It is axiomatic that if ANY lower court was to nullify a Supreme Court decision with which Chief Justice Roberts agreed, he would come down on them with all of his might, and would have his minions in Congress preparing articles of impeachment. That SHOULD happen here, but don't hold your breath.

Do you realize, there at the Times, that every time you say SCOTUS *must* do something, Scalia, Thomas, Thomas, and Roberts all vow to themselves to vote the other way?

I'm not saying you shouldn't continue to write about the court's atrocities and tragedies -- of course you should -- but that you are unlikely to change the mind of justices who appear to take more pleasure in ticking off liberals than they do in ruling justly.

.
Our courts system is supposed to be a system of justice.  Have we lost sight of that?

Really nothing unexpected in this result, and as such, deserves about 1 paragraph in a newspaper. An agreement, especially if it was a good one, would have made sense.

That said, the focus should have been on the economy, not the debt. In looking at the actual numbers, it is not that spending has increased so much as it is that revenues have dropped dramatically. Fixing the economy would be the single biggest factor towards bringing down the deficits and slowing the growth in debt, not the other way around.

This committee and the automatic cuts in the case of failure are huge mistakes by congressional leaders and Obama in that they take focus away from the economy and reality, once again.

I watched the Woody Allen documentary instead of the game.  Why bother after all these years; we all know that the Giants will find a way to lose to Philadelphia regardless of place, time and personnel.

I couldn't ask for a better outcome, automatic spending cuts in all the right places. Defense cuts larger than either party has the courage to vote for on its own, Bush tax cuts ending, major social problems protected from Republican slash & burn tatics what more could a person ask for.

Now all we need is for the Democrats and the President to stand tall and hold the line. The Amercian people are smart enough to figure out who's doing what and for whom. The 99% will be hear and will vote to support those members willing to protect the bulk of Americans against those shielding the 1%.

I do wish that the media would stop making it sound like Arrmagedom if the special committee does not reach agreement, it is time to detail the automatic cuts and support them

Social Security could be tweaked as could Medicare. We could have opt-out clauses; means testing would be prudent; Medicaid rates-of-reimbursement should be increased, which will significantly decrease systemic fraud; electronic medical records on a national data base saves billions; increase the percent of income taxed for SS and Medicare. This should be a good starting point as far as the "big two" are concerned.
The bloated military budget should be cut regardless of the economic climate, end the Afghanistan intervention. Bring troops home from Germany and Japan and N.Korea too. End corporate welfare,and farm subsidies. Let the Bush tax cuts expire (on the 1%), add all the savings and we should be close to balancing a budget.
As for the debt.........legalize marijuana, the ripple effect will blow your mind!

What's with the fear of the "sequester"? That is exactly what needs to be done: Sequester these idiots in a very small very uncomfortable room and throw away the lock until they come to a reasonable agreement involving a balanced approach and demanding sacrifice of all the "untouchable" dogma and desires of all parties, including citizens, according to what they can reasonably give. I would suggest feeding them K-rations on a stretched out schedule so that they might better understand the plight of the poor, the sacrifice of the military, etc... while forcing them to watch one member per day eat filet mignon and quiche and drink fine wines and get to sit in a hot tub..... so that they can understand the frustrations of the unemployed and underprivileged.

Let them sense our daily resentment of their selfish greed.

Perhaps THAT type of sequester might get some results.

Doing nothing will actually result in spending cuts (sequestration) and increased revenue (Bush cuts expire). Reducing the debt is what Republicans ran on, so why are they so eager to go back on Defense cuts?

As for the Democrats, they proposed a $3 trillion package. They tried to come up with a grand bargain. However, Republicans refused to play ball - this plays well to moderates.

Ending the Bush tax cuts is worth $4+ trillion. The sequestration is worth $1.2 trillion. In the end, this will be good for everyone.
I'd sure like to know where the game was played....

You should have included this material in the newspaper article, instead of including entirely predictable propaganda from the Heritage Foundation and the like, which no one outside of professional politics takes seriously.

It seems like their incomes are reasonable for their skill levels, and it is unlikely they will make much more unless they either increase their hours or learn a new skill, both of which are difficult for people in their position.

They should be able to live decently on these incomes, and people did it in the past. They had smaller houses with lower property taxes in those days, nobody worried about medical costs, and you didn't need a fleet of vehicles. Things were still pretty tight, but people didn't worry as much because the economy was growing and incomes were rising.

#2
Housing prices are not artificially inflated, the government is not setting the prices it is those who have overpaid for their house and in many cases these people did everything correct. Allowing the values of their houses to depreciate any further will only exacerbate the continuing foreclosure and bankruptcy problems facing many underwater home owners. However, the reality is that the continued depreciation of homes will occur anyway and the prices will continue to drop; foreclosures will continue to be a drag on the economy; and bankruptcies will start to trend higher.
Given the number of families close to the proverty level and stagnant wages the state of the housing market will only add more households to the near poor.
The government chases jobs overseas with it's high taxes and massive regulation.  Ordinary Americans lose bargaining power as a result.

I agree with MM, but what would happen to all the home owners now if the value of their home descended to the levels you describe? It would be a nightmare and would represent the single greatest loss of wealth in our history. After so many years of people putting all their eggs in the home basket you would risk causing more problems than solving.

Unless somehow the government could step in and pad the pain felt in this arena, which of course we know this government is incapable of doing anything as long as a large number of congressman see any government intervention as a problem.
Well, Leah #7, if government got out of health care, then Medicare wouldn't pay for any treatments, because it wouldn't exist.

>> Here’s a clever idea for how to save Medicare some cash without hurting patients. Don’t pay for treatments found to be useless.<<

But don't you know that line of thinking leads to "Death Panels"?....so say Republicans.
